column1: https://www.joebucsfan.com/2025/01/bucs-fans-will-be-on-the-edge-of-their-seats/|Bucs Fans Will Be On The Edge Of Their Seats|BY IRA KAUFMAN This Buc offseason is all about trying to gain an edge. Don’t be fooled by the numbers. Todd Bowles always finds a way to stack up impressive sack totals
column2: but anyone who watched the 2024 Bucs knows this defense lacked a consistent pass rush. Although sacks tend to be drive killers
column3: consistent pressure is what defensive coordinators strive for. Tampa Bay’s pressure was wildly inconsistent
column4: whether the Bucs were chasing fleet quarterbacks like Lamar Jackson and Jayden Daniels or statues like Kirk Cousins and Jared Goff. The interior of the defensive line is stout
column5: manned by Vita Vea and upcoming star Calijah Kancey. It was Kancey who led the Bucs with 7.5 sacks last season
column6: two years after Vea posted a team-high 6.5 sacks. Still
column7: it’s a lot easier to assign resources to block Kancey and Vea when opposing offensive line coaches aren’t concerned about the pocket collapsing from outside pressure. Why would they be? YaYa Diaby is young and promising
column8: but last year proved he needs to raise his game. There will be changes. Say goodbye to Joe Tryon-Shoyinka. The Bucs could lose Anthony Nelson in free agency. If Will Gholston returns
column9: it will be to provide run support on early downs. Shaq Barrett’s journey back to Tampa is a nice story
column10: but let’s get real — he hasn’t offered much heat off the left side since 2021. Jason Licht has tried to land quarterback hunters off the edge in the draft
column11: to no avail. He found Barrett in free agency and traded for Jason Pierre-Paul
column12: two of the most astute moves by a Buc GM in decades. Together
column13: JPP and Barrett chased Patrick Mahomes all over Raymond James Stadium en route to a Vince Lombardi Trophy. That was then. What’s the front office going to do now? You won’t hear Bowles publicly bemoan the absence of accomplished edge rushers on the current roster. That’s not the way he rolls. But you can bet Bowles
column14: Licht and the Glazers are in firm agreement: finding an outside pass rush is Job 1 in the next three months. Picking at No. 19 in the first round
column15: the Bucs could find slim pickings in a draft that lacks a Myles Garrett or a Will Anderson at the top. Penn State’s Abdul Carter is the consensus top edge rusher
column16: but he’ll be long gone by the time Licht’s on the clock. Marshall’s Mike Green and James Pearce Jr. of Tennessee appear intriguing
column17: along with Georgia teammates Jalon Walker and Mykel Williams and Texas A&M teammates Nic Scourton and Sherman Stewart. It’s a longshot to expect anyone except Carter to make a major impact as a rookie. So where does that leave the Bucs? There’s a former FSU standout who will likely be available in free agency
column18: but Philadelphia’s Josh Sweat will attract plenty of suitors besides Tampa Bay. The Falcons
column20: Cardinals and Titans are some of the many teams also desperate for a dynamic edge rusher. Sweat’s no Garrett or T.J. Watt
column22: 61 QB hits and 31 tackles for loss in the past three seasons. The Eagles gave Sweat a 3-year contract extension in 2021 and Buc fans have an opportunity to see him hunting Patrick Mahomes in the Super Bowl. The Eagles probably can’t afford to keep Sweat
column23: who turns 28 in March. Licht is very tight with Philadelphia GM Howie Roseman
column24: who drafted Sweat in 2018 and would likely offer Licht a candid assessment of Sweat’s character and work ethic. Khalil Mack
column25: two years removed from a 17-sack season
column26: is also a potential free agent
column27: but he turns 34 next month and his play dropped off significantly with the Chargers in 2024. How about Hassan Reddick? No thank you. DeMarcus Lawrence? Pass. It’s up to the personnel department to find Bowles more tools for his defense. column1: https://www.joebucsfan.com/2025/01/cody-mauch/|Cody Mauch’s Improvement Helped Offensive Line Rise|One player Joe felt needed to pick things up for the 2024 season at times seemed overwhelmed in 2023. That would have been Bucs rookie guard Cody Mauch. Joe loved his heart and his attitude
column2: but there were games where it seemed like Mauch was not on the same level as NFL defensive lineman. Joe had confidence that if Mauch had a full offseason in an NFL weight room to bulk up
column3: he’d have a chance to improve. And that’s exactly what happened. Match that ornery attitude (between the lines — Mauch is actually a teddy bear off the field) with more bulk and you have a really solid player. In fact
column4: Kevin Patra of NFL.com thinks Mauch was an under-the-radar stud. Offensive linemen generally don’t get enough praise when they improve. Mauch deserves it for making a MASSIVE leap from Year 1 to Year 2. As a rookie
column5: the Buccaneers guard allowed 48 pressures and seven sacks. This season
column6: those numbers dropped to 18 pressures and two sacks. He went from a near liability as a run and pass blocker to a reason why Baker Mayfield and the offense continued to click. Given that he was playing next to a rookie center in Graham Barton
column7: Mauch’s rise is even more impressive. The Bucs offense as a whole improved in 2024 for a variety of reasons — Bucky Irving’s injection
column9: Mayfield’s continued improvement — but the offensive line’s bolstered play is up there. No one improved more than Mauch. That’s a great point Patra made about Mauch. He became a strong player despite playing next to a rookie center. Joe expects Graham Barton to be a better player next season (he has to work on those snaps) for the very same reasons Mauch was better: a combination of a full offseason in an NFL weight room and a year of NFL experience. Mauch was a big reason the Bucs offensive line became one of the better fronts in the game. Barton
column11: could make the line even better.|2025-01-29 03:45:00|345|16|8|Cody Mauch|Mauch's significant improvement from Year 1 to Year 2 praised.|5|Mixed sentiment with a range from optimism to criticism regarding various players and aspects of the team.|"{""commenter0"": {""username"": ""bob in valrico""

column1: https://www.joebucsfan.com/2025/01/bucs-may-hang-on-to-deion-jones/|Bucs May Hang On To Deion Jones|About eight years ago
column2: Deion Jones looked to be the next big thing at linebacker playing for the team that drafted him
column3: the Dixie Chicks. After the 2021 season
column4: the Dixie Chicks washed their hands of him
column5: despite him missing just 12 games in six seasons. That’s good durability. Since Atlanta parted ways with Jones
column6: he’s bounced around the NFL. He played three games for the Bucs at the end of this season because the Bucs were desperate for warm bodies due to injuries. Though he didn’t start a game for the Bucs
column7: Jones did have a pass defensed in the playoff loss to the Commandos. In his day-after presser following that game
column8: Bowles said Jones may have earned another look-see for the 2025 season. And the Bucs did just that by giving him a futures contract earlier this month. “Small sample size
column9: but we liked what we saw
column11: he’s very good in the pass game. He tackled okay. He did some things well. “I’d like to see more of him
column12: so we’ll see what the future holds but he’s a guy in hindsight that I’d like to have back.” Well
column13: the Bucs need inside linebackers in the worst way. And if (God forbid) Lavonte David hangs it up
column14: there is no doubt the biggest hole on the roster will be at inside linebacker. Bigger than the craters on Norv Turner’s face. Depending what David decides
column15: Joe would not be shocked if the Bucs signed a free agent linebacker in March and followed that up by drafting an inside linebacker. It might be wise to focus on Alabama linebacker Jihaad Campbell.|2025-01-29 00:00:00|276|21|6|Deion Jones|Bucs may retain Jones for future seasons.|2|Negative comments and criticism dominate the responses.|"{""commenter0"": {""username"": ""@Hands2theFace""
